question: 7 (b)
sols_html:
We want to be able to use part (a), so we need some way of converting the polynomial into something involving trigonometric functions. In particular, recall that

\(\displaystyle \tan^2 \theta +1 = \sec^2 \theta\)

so let’s try the substitution \(\displaystyle x = \tan \theta\), so \(\displaystyle dx = \sec^2 \theta \ d\theta\), and the boundaries of integration change according to \(\displaystyle x = -1 = \tan\theta \Rightarrow \theta = -\pi/4\) and \(\displaystyle x = 1 =\tan \theta \Rightarrow \theta = \pi/4\). Then, using symmetry at the end, as the resulting function is even, we see that

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{-1}^{1} \frac{dx}{(x^2+1)^3} &= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \frac{\sec^2\theta}{(\tan^2\theta+1)^3} \ d\theta \\ &= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \frac{\sec^2\theta}{(\sec^2\theta)^3} \ d\theta \\ &= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \frac{\sec^2\theta}{\sec^6\theta} \ d\theta \\ &= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \frac{1}{\sec^4\theta} \ d\theta \\ &= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \cos^4\theta \ d\theta \\ &= 2\int_{0}^{\pi/4} \cos^4\theta \ d\theta \\ &= 2\left(\frac{8+3\pi}{32}\right) \\ &= \frac{8+3\pi}{16}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We want to be able to use part (a), so we need some way of converting
the polynomial into something involving trigonometric functions. In
particular, recall that

$\displaystyle \tan^2 \theta +1 = \sec^2 \theta$

so let's try the substitution $\displaystyle x = \tan \theta$, so
$\displaystyle dx = \sec^2 \theta \ d\theta$, and the boundaries of
integration change according to
$\displaystyle x = -1 = \tan\theta \Rightarrow \theta = -\pi/4$ and
$\displaystyle x = 1 =\tan \theta \Rightarrow \theta =  \pi/4$. Then,
using symmetry at the end, as the resulting function is even, we see
that

\begin{align*}
\int_{-1}^{1} \frac{dx}{(x^2+1)^3} &= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \frac{\sec^2\theta}{(\tan^2\theta+1)^3} \ d\theta \\
&= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \frac{\sec^2\theta}{(\sec^2\theta)^3} \ d\theta \\
&= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \frac{\sec^2\theta}{\sec^6\theta} \ d\theta \\
&= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \frac{1}{\sec^4\theta} \ d\theta \\
&= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \cos^4\theta \ d\theta \\
&= 2\int_{0}^{\pi/4} \cos^4\theta \ d\theta \\
&= 2\left(\frac{8+3\pi}{32}\right) \\
&= \frac{8+3\pi}{16}
\end{align*}
